text: The name of the program is always in sys.argv[0]
The first element of sys.argv is always either the name of the script itself, or an empty string.
If sys.argv has only one element, then there must have been no arguments.
As others have said, you can check if any args were passed in by doing:

code:
#!/usr/bin/env python

import sys
args = sys.argv[1:]

if args:
    for arg in args:
        if arg == "do":
            # do this
else:
    print "usage is bla bla bla"

text: However, there is a Python module called OptParse that was developed explicitly for parsing command line arguments when running a script.
I would suggest looking into this, as it's a bit more "standards compliant" (As in, it's the expected and accepted method of command line parsing within the Python community).

code:
#!/usr/bin/env python

import sys
args = sys.argv[1:]

if args:
    for arg in args:
        if arg == "do":
            # do this
else:
    print "usage is bla bla bla"

import sys
args = sys.argv[1:]

for arg in args:
    if arg == "do":
        # do this

if not args:
    print "usage is bla bla bla"
